string.description: Accessibility description for the back button displayed in the top corner of the VR application to go back to the previous screen. [CHAR LIMIT=50]
string.name: back_button_content_description

string.description: Short text shown in a button in the dialog box that shows up to help users configure their Cardboard experience. By clicking on this button, the user will cancel the setup flow and return to their previous activity. [CHAR LIMIT=20]
string.name: cancel_button

string.description: Button text when the user is prompted with an action but can refuse that action. This communicates that the user has understood the dialog but wishes to take no further action, similar to CANCEL. [CHAR LIMIT=30]
string.name: dialog_button_got_it

string.description: Button text when the user is prompted to open the Daydream Help Center. [CHAR LIMIT=40]
string.name: dialog_button_open_help_center

string.description: Text shown in a dialog telling the user that their phone is not a Daydream-compatible phone, also directing them to the Daydream Help Center website. [CHAR LIMIT=200]
string.name: dialog_message_incompatible_phone

resources.string: A Daydream-ready phone is required. Visit the Daydream Help Center for more information.

string.description: Text shown inside the dialog box that shows up to help users configure their Cardboard experience. This string is displayed when the user doesn't have the cardboard app installed. [CHAR LIMIT=200]
string.name: dialog_message_no_cardboard

resources.string: Get the Cardboard app in order to configure your viewer.

string.description: Text shown inside the dialog box that shows up to help users configure their Cardboard experience. [CHAR LIMIT=200]
string.name: dialog_message_setup

resources.string: Set up your viewer for the best experience.

string.description: Short text for the title of the dialog box that shows up to help users configure their Cardboard experience. [CHAR LIMIT=30]
string.name: dialog_title

string.description: Short title text for the dialog telling the user that their phone is incompatible. [CHAR LIMIT=30]
string.name: dialog_title_incompatible_phone

string.description: Short title text for the dialog telling the user that additional setup is required (for VrCore). [CHAR LIMIT = 30]
string.name: dialog_title_vr_core_not_enabled

string.description: Short title text for the dialog telling the user that installation is required (for VrCore). [CHAR LIMIT = 30]
string.name: dialog_title_vr_core_not_installed

string.description: Title of warning dialogs shown to user. [CHAR LIMIT=25]
string.name: dialog_title_warning

string.description: Dialog to show before redirecting user to VrListenerService Settings. [CHAR LIMIT=250]
string.name: dialog_vr_core_not_enabled

resources.string: This application may not work properly without enabling Google VR Services, please enable this in phone Settings before continuing.

string.description: Dialog to show before redirecting user to download VrCore. [CHAR LIMIT=250]
string.name: dialog_vr_core_not_installed

resources.string: This application may not work properly without Google VR Services. Please install Google VR Services from the Play Store before continuing.

string.description: Short text shown in a button in the dialog box that shows up to help users configure their Cardboard experience. By clicking on this button, the user goes to the Cardboard app page on Playstore. [CHAR LIMIT=30]
string.name: go_to_playstore_button

string.description: Short text shown in a button in the dialog box that allows users to open Settings for Google VR Services. [CHAR LIMIT=30]
string.name: go_to_vr_listeners_settings_button

string.description: Google VR component name used for enabling VR mode
string.name: gvr_vr_mode_component

string.description: Error message displayed as a Toast when Android could not find a browser to open a website. [CHAR LIMIT=50]
string.name: no_browser_text

resources.string:
A roller coaster is an amusement ride developed for amusement parks and modern theme parks.
\n\nThe 360 video below shows the roller coaster movement.

The oldest roller coasters are believed to have originated from the so-called "Russian Mountains", which were specially-constructed hills of ice, located in an area that would later become St. Petersburg.[3] Built in the 17th century, the slides were built to a height of between 21 and 24 m (70 and 80 feet), consisted of a 50-degree drop, and were reinforced by wooden supports.


A toboggan-like sled was raised to the top of a track which consisted of hundreds of rollers. This Roller Toboggan then took off down gently rolling hills to the floor. The inventors of this ride, Stephen E. Jackman and Byron B. Floyd, claim that they were the first to use the term "roller coaster".


 Many safety systems are implemented in roller coasters. One of these is the block system. Most large roller coasters have the ability to run two or more trains at once, and the block system prevents these trains from colliding. In this system, the track is divided into several sections, or blocks. Only one train at a time is permitted in each block. At the end of each block, there is a section of track where a train can be stopped if necessary (either by preventing dispatch from the station, closing brakes, or stopping a lift). Sensors at the end of each block detect when a train passes so that the computer running the ride is aware of which blocks are occupied. When the computer detects a train about to travel into an already occupied block, it uses whatever method is available to keep it from entering. The trains are fully automated.

string.description: Message asking the user to place their phone into Cardboard. This is a generic message used in the absence of knowing the current viewer. [CHAR LIMIT=50]
string.name: place_your_phone_into_cardboard

resources.string: Place your phone into your Cardboard viewer

string.description: Message format asking the user to place their phone into the Cardboard compatible viewer that is currently configured. [CHAR LIMIT=50]
string.name: place_your_viewer_into_viewer_format

resources.string: Place your phone into your %s viewer

string.description: Accessibility description for the settings button displayed at the bottom of a VR application. [CHAR LIMIT=50]
string.name: settings_button_content_description

string.description: Short text shown in a button in the dialog box that shows up to help users configure their Cardboard experience. By clicking on this button, the user is taken to the Cardboard app to setup their Cardboard viewer. [CHAR LIMIT=30]
string.name: setup_button

string.description: Text which when pressed, takes the user to the view that allows them to switch their Cardboard compatible viewer. [CHAR LIMIT=10]
string.name: switch_viewer_action

string.description: Prompt asking if the user wants to switch their Cardboard compatible viewer. [CHAR LIMIT=45]
string.name: switch_viewer_prompt
